Intervention: Manual Lymphatic Drainage Treatment (MLD) 3 times a week for 4 weeks to the upper lymphedemic limb

Manual Lymph Drainage (MDD): MLD is a manual massage technique applied by the practitioner, designed to reduce limb volume in lymphedema patients by improving the movement of lymphatic fluid, resulting in a reduction in interstitial fluid.
PhysioTouch (negative pressure massage) treatment 3 times a week for 4 weeks at the upper limb lymphedema

PhysioTouch: PhysioTouch is a portable device that administers a negative pressure under the treatment head, and gently pulls the underlying skin and subcutaneous tissue into the suction cup. This suction produces a stretching on the skin and in the subcutaneous space. This action is designed to facilitate the lymphatic flow of interstitium into the lymphatic vessels, and mobilizes the superficial fascia.
Eligibility: CRITERIA FOR INCLUSION:
To be included, women must:
Be over 18 years of age;
Have received cancer treatment including surgery, radiotherapy (RT) and/or chemotherapy (CTX);
Have completed active cancer treatment at least one year before being enrolled in the study;
A lymphedema (LE) was diagnosed at least one year prior to enrolment in the study;
Have lymphedema of the arm on one side;
• Confirmed the LE on the basis of bioimpedance measurements with a L-Dex® score of >7.1 (note - it is a very light lymphedema);

The LE will be considered "stable" if, during the 3 months prior to registration, there has been no infection in the arm requiring antibiotics, no change in the ability to perform daily LE-related activities, and no subjective relationship of significant persistent changes in the volume of members;
Be mentally and physically capable of participating in the study;
Be able to attend sessions at the University of California campus, San Francisco (UCSF) Parnasus;
Read and understand English;
To be able to understand a written informed consent document and the willingness to sign it
- EXCLUSION CRITERIA
Women cannot have:
The bilateral upper end LE;
• Current infection or lymphangitis involving the affected arm;
Current recurrence of breast cancer (BC) (local or remote)
- the pre-existing pre-diagnosis of B.C.;
A condition that prevents the measurement of LE using bioimpedance spectroscopy (BIS), including pregnancy;
Current venous thrombosis in the upper extremities or in current anticoagulant therapy;
• An edema of the extremity due to heart failure
Results: The recruitment rate is defined as the number of women who were tested and then enrolled in the study, divided by the total number of women tested overall.
